title: PTD Today — Media
disclaimer: Informational only — AI-generated summaries; may contain errors. Verify with the original video.

items.title: How AI Empowers Artists. Watch the full episode on our channel now.

ai.summary: Based on the available description, this short film accompanies Season 5 of the Webby Award–winning podcast "Where the Internet Lives," examining the unseen world of data centers as they relate to AI, data, and creative practice. The episode ties the theme of how AI empowers artists to the infrastructure that enables digital creativity.
bullets: Film ties Season 5 of the podcast to themes of AI, data, and creativity.
Focuses on the 'unseen world' of data centers that support digital art and AI-powered workflows.
Published by Google on 2026-01-15; no transcript is available.
Associated hashtags: #WhereTheInternetLives #AI #Data #Creativity
takeaways: AI-driven creative workloads highlight the need to plan capacity and flexible power procurement for evolving demand profiles.
Energy efficiency, cooling strategy, and load management remain critical to reliably host AI and creative services at scale.
Integrating renewables, storage, and demand-response can help manage variability from bursty AI workloads tied to creative production.
Hardware refreshes to support AI (GPUs/accelerators) imply attention to critical-minerals supply chains and lifecycle planning.
Engage with creative-platform stakeholders to forecast workload patterns and align infrastructure investments with real usage.

items.title: Boosting AI Performance: Networking for AI Inference

ai.summary: Based on the available description, Victor Moreno from Google Cloud explains how networking must become AI-aware to support modern inference workloads. Google Cloud’s approach uses the GKE Inference Gateway, AI-aware load balancing and service extensions (like network-level guardrails) to improve GPU utilization, reduce latency, and simplify governance for model deployments.
bullets: Traditional metrics (e.g., CPU) and round-robin load balancing can send traffic to GPU‑congested replicas and increase latency.
GKE Inference Gateway and AI-aware load balancing use inference-specific signals (KV cache utilization, queue depth) to identify least‑loaded replicas.
Techniques include prefix caching (reusing prefill computations), body‑based routing for model identification, and LoRA adapter awareness to reduce GPU work.
Service Extensions let API management and AI guardrails run in the network path to sanitize prompts/responses before they hit GPUs.
Outcomes reported: fewer cold starts, higher GPU saturation (lower TCO), improved developer velocity via unified APIs, and compute cost savings by blocking invalid requests early.
takeaways: Higher GPU saturation from AI‑aware routing reduces energy per inference and can lower overall data center power and cooling demand.
Network‑level guardrails that block invalid or out‑of‑policy prompts save wasted GPU cycles, directly cutting compute costs and energy use.
Caching and prefill reuse smooth peak GPU load, enabling more predictable capacity planning for power provisioning, UPS, and cooling.
Reduced latency and fewer cold starts improve SLA compliance for latency‑sensitive services, affecting prioritization of networking and edge resources.
Unified networking and API management can simplify operations and speed deployments, which may reduce staffing and integration overhead in data center operations.

items.title: Where Winds Meet is #RTXOn with DLSS 4 with Multi Frame Generation

ai.summary: Based on the available description, this NVIDIA GeForce video showcases the open-world martial arts RPG Where Winds Meet running with DLSS 4 and Multi Frame Generation, promoted with #RTXOn. The short clip credits DigitalDreamsyt and no transcript is provided.
bullets: Open-world martial arts RPG: Where Winds Meet
Showcases NVIDIA DLSS 4 with Multi Frame Generation (MFG)
Promoted with #RTXOn visual branding
Credits: DigitalDreamsyt
No transcript available; description is brief
takeaways: DLSS 4 and MFG are GPU-side features aimed at improving rendering throughput—if effective, they can reduce energy per rendered frame or increase server throughput for cloud gaming/visualization.

Higher achievable frame rates and visual fidelity enabled by RTX/DLSS may increase sustained GPU utilization in datacenter or cloud-gaming deployments, with corresponding impacts on power draw and cooling requirements.

Ongoing demand for modern GPUs that support features like DLSS 4 could influence procurement timing and capacity planning for data centers, and indirectly affect supply-chain pressure on critical-minerals used in GPUs.

Operators should consider these trends when planning power, cooling, and UPS capacity for game-streaming or GPU-accelerated services, and evaluate whether efficiency gains from advanced upscaling offset higher utilization.

items.title: The backbone of your steam plant’s reliability | GE Vernova

ai.summary: Based on the available description, GE Vernova’s video highlights the importance of anticipating the remaining life of aging steam turbine rotors and deciding appropriate end-of-life actions. It frames the rotor as the backbone of steam-plant reliability and points viewers to GE Vernova resources for assessing rotor EOL and next steps.
bullets: Focus on assessing remaining life of steam turbine rotors to maintain plant reliability.
Emphasizes planning for end-of-life (EOL) actions rather than reactive fixes.
Positions the rotor as central to overall steam-plant availability and performance.
Directs viewers to GE Vernova resources for rotor EOL assessment and guidance.
Published on GE Vernova’s channel as part of broader asset-lifecycle and decarbonization messaging.
takeaways: Prioritize rotor life assessments to reduce risk of unplanned outages and preserve grid/data-center power reliability.
Use EOL planning to schedule maintenance, budgeting, or retrofit decisions well before critical failures.
Consider OEM resources and lifecycle services (e.g., from GE Vernova) when evaluating replacement, refurbishment, or upgrade options.
Align rotor decisions with broader decarbonization and efficiency goals to optimize long-term asset value.

items.title: Rynek dóbr luksusowych w obliczu transformacji | Andrzej Marczak, Tomasz Wiśniewski

ai.summary: Based on the available description, this KPMG ON AIR episode discusses how the luxury goods market is changing — highlighting trends such as "luxury fatigue," the concentration of spending among the very wealthy, growth of "affordable luxury," rising demand for experiences and personalization, and stronger ESG expectations. The hosts also compare Poland to global markets, cover luxury tourism and art, and look ahead to AI, craftsmanship and human-centric service as drivers of the sector's future.
bullets: Macro trends: "luxury fatigue," concentrated spending (top 2% = ~40% of market), and growth of "affordable luxury."
Consumer shifts: Gen Z prioritizes experiences over ownership; personalization and exclusive experiences are central.
ESG and responsible luxury: demand for sustainable materials (e.g., eco-leathers), certifications and transparent practices.
Poland-specific: market is growing but fragmented, with rising luxury tourism (coastal resorts, hotels, spas) and an active contemporary art scene.
Future focus: AI-enabled services, continued craftsmanship, and stronger brand-world storytelling (hotels, film) shaping luxury experiences.
takeaways: Anticipate localized increases in electricity demand and resilience needs where luxury hotels, spas and premium tourism develop — plan distribution upgrades, backup power and targeted peak-management.
ESG-driven sourcing creates demand for renewable-backed supply and green certifications; consider offering green PPAs, on-site renewables and storage solutions to luxury operators.
AI and personalization trends imply higher compute and low-latency requirements — evaluate capacity for additional data-center or edge compute growth, plus associated cooling and power-density needs.

Expansion of "affordable luxury" broadens the consumer base and retail footprint, potentially increasing distributed load (charging, HVAC, lighting) — monitor for new load hotspots and EV charging integration.

Procurement for premium tech and AI infrastructure may expose operators to critical-minerals supply risks; incorporate supply-chain resilience and lifecycle/ESG considerations into sourcing decisions.

items.title: PJM: Reliable Electricity is Our Priority

ai.summary: Based on the available description, the video highlights PJM Interconnection's long-standing focus on reliability since 1927. It provides an overview of how PJM works to help ensure electricity is available when customers and businesses need it.
bullets: PJM has prioritized electricity reliability since 1927.
The video explains PJM’s role in keeping electricity available for customers and businesses.
Emphasis is on operational practices and coordination to maintain service.
Intended as an overview to build understanding of PJM’s reliability mission.
takeaways: Data center operators should maintain and coordinate redundancy and emergency plans with their utility/PJM to align with regional reliability practices.
Grid and substation planners benefit from ongoing engagement with PJM to reflect reliability priorities in transmission and capacity planning.
Renewables and storage projects need to consider regional operator requirements so integration supports, rather than strains, system reliability.
Procurement and supply-chain teams (including for critical minerals tied to storage/generation) should factor in stable grid operation expectations when assessing demand and timing.

ai.summary: Based on the available description, the video frames grid modernization as the need to balance reliability, flexibility and efficiency while expanding capacity to support the energy transition. It positions Hitachi Energy’s digitally centric power‑grid technologies as tools to improve system stability, reduce downtime, and optimize performance across the network.
bullets: Modernization must deliver reliability, flexibility and efficiency alongside capacity growth.
Digital technologies are presented as central to improving grid stability and performance.
Primary benefits called out: reduced downtime and optimized operational performance.
Framing links capacity expansion to enabling the broader energy transition.
Hitachi Energy is positioned as a provider of digital-enabled grid solutions.
takeaways: Prioritize digital-first grid investments to boost stability and minimize downtime for critical loads like data centers.
Design capacity expansions with equal emphasis on flexibility and efficiency to accommodate more renewables and storage.
Assess vendors on their ability to deliver digital tools that optimize performance across substations and system levels.
Operational resilience (less downtime) should be a key procurement metric when modernizing grid or data‑center power infrastructure.
